description: Tools related to display technology, cameras, media servers, related software and other concepts

children.description: Physical computing devices and components used in creative technology projects.
Devices and methods for presenting or exporting digital content, like displays, speakers, and printers.
Screens and monitors that visually present digital information, from CRTs to modern flatscreens.
Display technologies found in common consumer electronics like TVs, phones, and laptops.
Older, outdated display and output technologies no longer widely used, like CRT TVs and dot-matrix printers.
Older TV technology that uses a cathode ray tube to generate images on a phosphor-coated screen.
Display technology that uses electrically charged ionized gas to illuminate pixels and create images.
Television technology that creates the illusion of three-dimensional images, often using specialized glasses.
Thin, flat display technologies like LCD, LED, and OLED that have largely replaced bulky CRT displays.
Thin, flexible light-emitting panels used for displays, lighting, and interactive surfaces.
Organic light-emitting diode displays with self-emitting pixels for vibrant, high-contrast images.
Liquid crystal displays that use a backlight to produce images, offering cost-effective display solutions.
Quantum dot LED displays that offer improved color accuracy and energy efficiency over traditional LCDs.
Emerging display technology with microscopic LEDs for high-resolution, high-brightness, and energy-efficient displays.
Devices that project images or video onto a screen or surface, enabling large-scale visual displays.
Techniques for capturing, processing, and displaying visual information, such as photography, videography, and digital imaging.
Digital light processing, a projection technology that uses a digital micromirror device to create images.
Compact, portable projectors that can display images and videos from smartphones, tablets, and other devices.
Compact, portable projection systems for small spaces and presentations.
High-lumen, high-resolution projectors for large event spaces and auditoriums.
Specialized displays for digital signage, retail, and commercial applications.
Light-emitting diode technology used for displays, lighting, and creative installations.
Synchronized multi-display systems for large-scale, high-resolution visual experiences.
Projection-based or LED-embedded floors that respond to user movement and interaction.
3D displays that create visual content in a true three-dimensional space.
Display and projection technologies designed for use in controlled indoor environments.
Displays and projection systems that incorporate transparent or see-through elements.
Displays and projection systems designed for use in outdoor environments and weather conditions.
Displays designed for continuous indoor use, often with high brightness and reliability.
Devices that project images or video onto a screen or surface, enabling large-scale visual displays.
Organic Light-Emitting Diode displays that produce their own light, enabling high contrast and energy efficiency.
Displays designed to withstand outdoor environmental conditions like rain, snow, and extreme temperatures.
Liquid Crystal Display technology that uses an electric current to control light-emitting pixels.
LG's Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) technology for medical imaging and visualization applications.
Light-Emitting Diode displays that use an array of LED lights to produce images and video.
Emerging display technologies beyond traditional LCD and LED, such as e-ink, quantum dot, and holographic.
Displays that capture and reproduce the direction of light, enabling 3D visualization without glasses.
Product from Light Field Labs, not yet released in early 2025
Product that uses hundreds of individual projectors to make an actual light field above the display
OLED displays that are partially transparent, allowing for unique display applications and integrations.
Displays with multiple layers that can create depth and 3D effects.
LCD displays that are partially transparent, enabling see-through effects.
Displays with multiple layers that can create depth and 3D effects.
Organic LED displays that can bend and flex, enabling new form factors.
Company may be out of commission as of 2025, but previous had several flexible display kits
Flexible OLED displays developed by LG, used in smartphones and other devices.
Flexible OLED displays developed by BOE, a leading display manufacturer.
Reflective display technology that mimics the appearance of ink on paper.
A company that develops electronic paper (E-Ink) solutions for various applications.
Electronic paper displays developed by Samsung, known for their low power consumption.
Displays that can create 3D images in physical space, without the need for glasses.
Transparent screens stacked to create depth and layered visuals.
Strands of LED pixels arranged in a physical volume
LCD displays with altered polarizers to create unique visual effects.
Various approaches to autostereoscopic displays, both spatial and temporal multiplexing
Lenticular autostereoscopic displays from small to large
Not technically auto-stereoscopic, but seems like it could fall into this category. A tilable high resolution LED wall that uses passive polarized glasses to create a 3D image from a large LED wall
Temporally multiplexed image technique for creating 3D holographic-like visuals.
Creative methods and approaches for developing innovative visual experiences.
Projecting images and visuals onto water surfaces for unique, fluid displays.
Projecting visuals onto fog or mist to create ethereal, floating displays.
Optical illusion where a visual image appears to persist due to the eye's persistence.
Optical illusion technique using a transparent surface to create the appearance of a ghostly image.
Projection of 3D visuals into physical space, creating the illusion of floating holographic images.
Techniques that manipulate light and visuals to create unique, abstract, or distorted effects.
Laser projection technology for unique, high-quality visuals with vibrant colors and sharp images.
Displays that break from the traditional rectangular format, offering creative and immersive visual experiences.
Innovative, often custom-built display technologies that push the boundaries of conventional visual interfaces.
Electronically switchable glass that can transition between transparent and opaque states, enabling dynamic visual effects.
Paint that can change color or opacity when an electric current is applied, enabling interactive and responsive surfaces.
Thermochromic paint, glow in the dark, etc
The use of plasma, a state of matter consisting of ionized gases, to create unique visual and interactive effects.
The use of high-frequency sound waves to suspend and manipulate small objects in mid-air, enabling novel display and interaction techniques.
Displays that use various mechanical methods, such as moving parts or actuators, to present images and information.
A type of mechanical display that uses an array of small, individually controlled flipping dots to create low-resolution images and text.
Mechanical display using flipping panels to show text or images, often used for signage.
Input devices that detect touch, enabling direct interaction with on-screen content.
Touch technology using a grid of electrodes to detect changes in capacitance, enabling multi-touch.
Touch technology using infrared light to detect finger position, often used in large displays.
Touch technology using two conductive layers that register touch when pressed together, enabling single-touch.
Touch technology using ultrasonic waves to detect touch, enabling multi-touch and high accuracy.
Touch technology using a conductive coating to detect changes in capacitance, enabling multi-touch.
Technology that identifies physical objects or markers placed on a touch screen, enabling tangible interactions.
Devices and methods for providing data and commands to a computer or interactive system, including touch, gesture, voice, etc.
Devices that capture visual information, enabling various interactive and creative applications.
Technology for transmitting live video and audio content to viewers or listeners.
Pan-Tilt-Zoom cameras that can be remotely controlled to capture dynamic video footage.
Digital Single Lens Reflex cameras that offer advanced image quality and creative control.
High-end video cameras and equipment designed for professional filmmaking and cinematography.

name.en: See sensor category for more cameras

children.description: This was primarily meant for professional cameras. See sensor category for more cameras.
The process of recording video, audio, or other media content from a source to a storage device.
Hardware devices that allow users to capture video and audio from various sources to a computer.
A leading manufacturer of professional video cameras, capture cards, and other creative technology tools.
A video-over-IP technology that enables high-quality, low-latency video transmission over a network.
Adapters that allow users to capture HDMI video and audio input directly to a computer via USB.
Manufacturer of professional video production hardware and software tools for filmmakers and content creators.
Broader creative technology concepts beyond specific tools, such as color grading, motion graphics, and virtual production.
Devices that extend the range and quality of audio, video, and control signals over long distances.
Optical fiber cables that transmit data, video, and audio signals with high bandwidth and low latency.
Ethernet cable standards that provide high-speed data and video transmission for networking and AV applications.
Network devices that direct and manage data traffic between connected devices, enabling communication and internet access.
Hardware devices that connect multiple input sources and route them to one or more output destinations.
Technologies and protocols for delivering audio, video, and data over networks and the internet in real-time.
Cables and connectors used to transmit high-quality video and audio signals between devices, such as HDMI, SDI, and DisplayPort.
Older, outdated technologies and standards that are still in use, such as analog video, serial connections, and legacy audio formats.
Serial Digital Interface, a standard for uncompressed digital video transmission over coaxial cable.
Video Graphics Array, an analog interface standard for connecting a display to a computer.
Radio Corporation of America, a type of analog connector commonly used for audio/video signals.
Coaxial cable, a type of electrical cable that has an inner conductor surrounded by a tubular insulating layer.
A video display resolution that has more than 2 million pixels, offering a sharper, more detailed image.
High-Definition Multimedia Interface, a digital audio/video interface used to transmit uncompressed video and audio.
A digital display interface standard used to connect a video source to a display device.
High-Definition Serial Digital Interface, a standard for uncompressed, all-digital transmission of HD video signals.
Third-generation SDI, a standard that supports HD video resolutions up to 1080p60 over a single coaxial cable.
Sixth-generation SDI, a standard that supports 4K video resolutions up to 4096x2160 at 60fps over a single coaxial cable.
Versatile software for playing various media formats on computers and devices.
Dedicated digital signage hardware and software platform for creating and managing displays.
Some Media servers have dedicated hardware and some are hybrids that have a software component and dedicated hardware platform. This category captures ones that have dedicated hardware
Powerful media server software for professional AV applications and live events.
Formerly known as d3, a leading platform for designing, previewing, and operating live shows and installations.
Comprehensive multi-display presentation and show control software for live events and installations.
High-performance media servers and software for large-scale projection mapping and live events.
A broad category encompassing various software tools for creative technology applications.
Tools for live visual performance, projection mapping, and real-time media manipulation.
Software for performing live visuals, video mixing, and projection mapping.
Powerful VJ software for live video mixing, compositing, and effects.
Projection mapping software for creating dynamic, interactive displays.
Versatile VJ and video mapping software for live performances and installations.
Cloud-based projection planning tool for visualizing and designing projection mappings.

name.en: Media Servers or Large Scale Tools

children.description: High-performance software and hardware for managing and controlling large-scale media displays.
Powerful media server software for real-time video processing and projection mapping.
Flexible media server software for live events, installations, and broadcast applications.
Formerly known as d3, a powerful platform for designing, previewing, and controlling complex visual experiences.
Comprehensive multi-display presentation and show control software for large-scale productions.
Real-time visual effects and motion graphics tool for live events, installations, and broadcast.
Media server and visual control platform for live events and installations.
Real-time 3D graphics and presentation software for live events and broadcast.
Comprehensive stage management software for live events and productions.
High-performance media servers for large-scale projection mapping and immersive experiences.
The process of delivering audio and video content over the internet in real-time.
The set of rules and standards that govern the transmission of streaming media over the internet.
Real-Time Messaging Protocol, a popular streaming protocol for live video and audio delivery.
Real-Time Streaming Protocol, a network control protocol for establishing and controlling media sessions.
HTTP Live Streaming, an adaptive bitrate streaming protocol developed by Apple for delivering media content.
Real-Time Transport Protocol, a standard packet format for delivering audio and video over the internet.
Network-based video and audio transport protocol for live production workflows.
Open Broadcaster Software for live streaming, recording, and video production.
Live production and streaming software with multi-camera support and professional features.
Live video mixing, production, and streaming software for Windows PCs.
